Filament required depending of settings ~ 8 Meters / 26 feet / print time about 3 hours.
Happy printing!
No support material required, just print, add the bearings and bolts / nuts and enjoy!

description.text: This is a variation on my keychain with rotateable gears. This keychain features a working 4-slotted geneva mechanism. It has a lenght of around 6 cm. I have added 3 holders with different clearances between the diameter of the shafts and the diameter of the holes in the wheels.

Step 1) Print the geneva wheel and the pin wheel
Step 2) Print the holder and the dummy at same time
Step 3) Pause your 3D-printer when the printhead is located at the dummy and just before the bridge structure of the holder is going to be printed
Step 4) Place the wheels ( make sure that the dummy s located far enough of the holder so that you can place both wheels)
Step 5) Continue the print
Step 6) Your keychain is ready
( I have printed it with a prusa i3 / layer height: 0.2mm / 0.5 mm nozzle/ sliced with slic3r)
It is the logo/badge of the Italian aftermarket brand, Abarth. Fair warning: where I designed it based off an image on google, the actual badge is quite large so you'll have to resize it.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3o44GnkpvhI This thing is customizable with the tinkercad editor, you can change profile depth and amount of profile on the tire. Or just print it without any profile at all. This tire is meant for a small robot with embedded Linux made by Parrot: http://www.parrot.com/usa/products/jumping-sumo/ I found the original tires to slipery and this tire adds some traction if printed with a flexible PLA like Filaflex of Ninjaflex.

remixed_from.author: Yngel
remixed_from.title: Medium size lasercut log cabin for 28 mm(ish) tabletop gaming

title: Large lasercut log cabin for 28 mm tabletop gaming

description.text: A fairly large, modular log cabin built with actual lasercut logs, intended for 28mm miniature gaming scenery. Use 3.2 mm (1/8 inch) material. This is a fairly time consuming build, as it consists of a LOT of small pieces. The modular nature of the building allows you to choose how many floors you want to add. Part 1-5 is a two storey building, and there's an extra file with an additional floor that can be printed in as many copies as you have the patience to build.The three rings can be glued together to build something resembling a brick built well. The details around the doors and windows are a bit thick at 3.2 mm, and might just look better if cut from thinner material. I've made some slight symmetry changes from the prototype that I haven't test built yet in the uploaded files. Please let me know if I've made any mistakes.

I've added instructions in the download section. The logs are designed to sit slightly loosely in the vertical direction, allowing the building to be slightly less neat than laser cutting normally allows. Log cabins aren't supposed to look laser perfect.

comments.text: I'm glad you found it interesting. It's not an easy build, I'm afraid, and I'm not entirely sure about the scale, but I hope it can work as scenery.

author: Yngel

description.text:
After I found the really cool looking Rubber Band Gun from KAZKIN, I soon realized that I must have such a thing. But can't buy one or get the right plans to build it on my own. So I've tried to make my own cool Gun, for the normal "Monday morning office war"
And of course for my son :-))))

I'm sure most of you don't need any advice, but you should make all Parts as strong as possible.
That Thing is almost complete printable, you just need a small Spring an two screws. I made the holes for a M3 screw tap.
The bolts are intentionally a little bit too long, cause you have to correct the upper/lower edge after printing and it's easier just shorten them. Sometimes you have to care about the edges of the holes to, depending on which PLA/ABS and/or Printer you use.
i hope you enjoy this Toy and publish many pics of your own copy.
Just by the way, the Chassis is about 6 hours and the other Parts are 3-4 hours printing time.
But it is worth it... I've added the frame as individual files and even a new slightly larger med sitze Frame, also single Files for left & right.

remixed_from.author: satoer
remixed_from.title: E3D V5 hotend easy maintenance carriage for Felix 3D printer

title: E3D V6 hotend easy maintenance carriage for Felix 3D printer

description.text:
After lot of requests, I’ve updated the E3D V5 hot end carriage to the E3D V6 Hot end.
The hot end clamp is completely redesigned, but the baseplate and fan duct are the same. So if you upgrade from the V5, you only have to print the “cooler base” and “cooler door”
This hot-end carriage makes the bowden tube E3D hot-end V6 ( http://e3d-online.com/ ) compatible with the Felix 3D printer (1.5 and up). It's designed for the felix Printer, but can easily be adjusted for other printers as well. Just fit it with two bolds against the rails.
The hot-end can easily be removed by unscrewing 2 bolds and opening the door.
It’s specifically design for the V6 version, The v5 or if a newer version comes up with a new layout cool-ribs, it will not fit. The cool ribs are printed inside the PLA clamp.
If you need a V5 version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159142
It uses 40mm fans (not the E3D supplied 30mm fan) More cooling, less noise. (and comes standard with the Felix printer)
This is a two part design. The other part is the Bowden feeder:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:159159
Here's a instructional video of the (V5) carriage and bowden feeder in use:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZsNm0UfQsyQ
Special thanks to Guillaume from Felix printers to supply the rail-base.
If you use it, please share a picture!

Print without support. The Cooler door has built in support in the arcs. It’s probably not necessary but the clamp is a tight fit, and the arc needs to be perfectly round. Without support it might sag. There’s also a support less version included.
Use M4 bolds and nuts to fit together. (the bolds for the duct go through the arm.

This is a really basic design for a laser cut sandwich type enclosure for the Colorduino, used to nicely diffuse the display. Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W31v942zk0s

Download the DXF or SVG and load up into your laser cutter. Required Parts
  • 4 - M3 Threaded Hex Spacers (min 20mm)
  • 8 - M3 Bolts
  • Colorduino
  • RGB LED Matrix
  • Laserable Material
  • Access to a Laser Cutter
    • The material thickness isn't particularly important but your choice of the front piece will affect how the LED's look through it (don't pick an opaque material!) I used 3mm Frosted Opal acrylic for the front and 3mm Birch Ply for the back. The two pieces are separated by threaded hex spacers, the shortest you can use is 20mm but I added an extra couple of nuts to diffuse the light a bit more softly.

comments.text: As an Airframe and Powerplant Technician, (Aircraft Mechanic) I see a few issues that need to be addressed with this design. First is judging from the size and weight of a GoPro camera and the electronics you will need in the airframe the wing (lifting body) looks too small. Also the front end will block airflow over most of your lifting surface. Make the entire airframe larger in relation to the front end/viewing window and that will fix most of this problem. Also you will need to make it more aerodynamic. It will need to be more pointy. You also will need to find the proper balance point for this to fly. Standard on most airplanes is 1/3 of the distance from the leading edge of the main wing to the trailing edge of the main wing. Since this is a lifting body it gets more complicated. Much testing will need to be done before actually launching this. I am not trying to dissuade you from trying this, just trying to help you get going in a good direction. Another suggestion is to make the viewing bubble or window hang more underneath the main wing. This would help with many of the issues I have brought up. Good luck!

comments.text: I will if the weight remains reasonable.  And before I put any expensive electronics I'd like to do a static launch first.  Realistically, I'd like to see the ship deployed using an ejection charge (like a piston launcher -- they have those in rocketry). I see that you have an elongated nose, which is what I will use.  I will put ballast to represent electronics and power supply and run the thing through my spreadsheet to make sure it can get to altitude.  Let me know what happens with your glide tests.

comments.text: Why don't we collaborate then?  I have been flying rockets for a long time, and I have a booster which I think can loft your prototype to about 1000-2000ft as a test.  My current vehicle has been test-shot on a rocket in 1/6 scale of the current sized one and I have installed now a camera, altimeter and BOSCAM FPV transmitter.  Send me a message directly with your eMail and let's talk.

comments.text: Ok sounds good but there is a lot of things to talk about. I work during the week but, we can talk more during the weekend. I am in. One thing that needs to be tested is the GPS to guide it back. I know there is an altitude limitation but I am wondering when the plane is alredy on way back down if it will regain a GPS lock.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: Ok sounds good but there is a lot of things to talk about. I work during the week but, we can talk more during the weekend. I am in. One thing that needs to be tested is the GPS to guide it back. I know there is an altitude limitation but I am wondering when the plane is alredy on way back down if it will regain a GPS lock.
comments.author: SkyRider

comments.text: There should be no altitude limit below the satellite unless we are talking about that at certain altitudes there can be no GPS lock because they are line of sight devices.  But I do know that a team in the UK was able to do this with a Rasberry Pi and onboard GPS (theirs was a balloon that took up the plane before it ignited its rocket engine and it flew to 100K+ feet.  We can send up a GPS and an Arduino up and when the balloon pops have it come down with a streamer before deploying a small chute for recovery.  Also, you should have GPS lock prior to blast off and even if you descend in a wide circle at FL50, you should still have enough sky time to lock and then navigate back home.  Definitely doable. description.text:
Designed this to replace the one I lost for my Leatherman Charge TTi.  Fits nice and snug, feels surprisingly strong.  
Update:  The original design had a critical weakness where it holds the bit so I redesigned it in two parts.  There is now a "belt" that press fits over the bit socket portion that should be printed such that the layer grain is at a 90 degree angle to the extension itself.  The belt completely solved the inherent weakness and I've been using this new version for months.

I printed this solid with a brim and a 90 degree rotation on the X axis at 0.2 layer height.  
If printing V2, print the extension as above and the belt such that the loops are each a layer.  (The grain of the print should be at a 90 degree angle relative to the extension)  As soon as the belt is finished you should press fit it onto the extension while it's still warm and slightly flexible.  The socket is very tight, so light sanding may be required for ease of removal of the bits.  The portion of the extension that inserts into the leatherman may also be a very tight fit and could benefit from some light sanding.

title: Extruder fan (50mm) for Printrbot Simple Metal

description.text:
This is a no-frills mount for a low-profile 50mm fan for the Printrbot Simple Metal 2014, to keep the extruder motor cool.  Holes are sized for countersunk self-tapping screws (the standard type that comes with PC fans.  There's no fan guard.  
A 50mm fan fits perfectly here.  A cheap source of 50mm fans are 3.5" hard drive coolers, which feature two of these fans, and costs the same or lower than trying to buy a standalone 50mm fan.  
I found that I had to rotate my bed sensor to accommodate the fan, but you could also flip the plate around and install the fan on the outside.  
I've also included the Sketchup file for ease resizing of screw-holes, etc.

This is my design for a puzzle box that uses centrifugal force to open the locks. I have seen centrifugal boxes before but none that had the locking mechanism totally in the lid,
This design includes an anti-pick mechanism that locks the locking slides in place to prevent opening by random shaking or tilting, a problem with my first prototype.
To unlock just spin (quite fast) and then lift the lid.
To lock, make sure the locks are in the unlock position, if not then just spin the lid to reset them. Then replace the lid and shake the box along its long axis. You will hear the locks engage and lock into place.
Enjoy.

You will need the following parts as well as the printed parts:
6 x UK 1p coins (or equivalent coins - US 1 Cent / washers, 20mm diameter)
2 x UK 2p coins (or equivalent coins - US Quarter / washers, 26mm diameter)
1 x small elastic band.
4 x M3 x 10mm screws (8-12mm will be ok) - optional.
Lid:
Print out the following:
2 x lock
2 x slide
1 x lid
1 x lid_floor
1 x handle
For the Base I have given two options;
For people who are using PLA or are gurus at printing ABS boxes without corner distortion there is the complete box base (base).
For lesser mortals such as myself I have split it into 3 parts, print:
2 x base_side1
2 x base_side2
1 x base_floor
Glue together.
Lid Assembly:
Please refer to the photos for more info.
You will require some washers or coins to make the box work. Its been designed for use with UK 1p and 2p pieces but should work with any metal disks that will add some mass, the more the better it will work. I will be referring to 1p and 2p coins in the description.
To assemble the locking pieces glue a 1p coin in the bottom of each lock. Cut a small elastic band and tie a knot or two in the end. Thread through from the inside of a locking piece to the inside of the other locking piece, Use one of the slides as a spacer and place the locks either side of the locking notch in the centre. Pull the elastic band so its straight but not stretched. Glue the elastic band in place and glue in two more 1p coins into the top of each lock. You should have an assembly like the one pictured. Don't worry too much about getting the tension right just now, it can be adjusted tighter in the final assembly.
Glue two 2p coins into the recesses in each slide.
Allow enough time for the glue to fully set.
Using sandpaper or a fine file give all surfaces a clean. The smoother these are the better the box will work. This will also remove any excess glue.
Final assembly:
The pillars in the lid have 4 holes that can be threaded M3 if you have some m3 screws available (or use self-tapping), if not the lid_base can be carefully glued into place in the last stage. If you have screws then tap the 4 pillars on the underside of the lid been careful not to strip or drive the tap too far in that it marks the top of the lid.
Glue the handle to the top of the lid.
Assemble the lock as follows.
Put into the lid over the four posts a slide with the coin visible.
Next put the locking pieces in, one with the coins showing, the other with the coins to the lid (see photo)
Put the second slide over the posts rotated so the coin is at the opposite end of the lid to the first slide and so the coin is not visible (recess towards the lid).
Hold the lid_base in place and hold the lid on its side. By moving the slides with your fingers you should feel the slide lock into place. Test both slides. Pressure will overcome the locks, don't worry, you just want them to engage and resist movement. Repeat the test for both slides with the box on its other side. If one of the slides moves freely and does not lock with the lid is on its side then the elastic band is not tight enough. Just remove the top slide and lift a lock out giving it a 360 degree twist, this will tighten the elastic band and give more locking force.
Repeat the above test until you are happy with the locking force. The more force the harder the box will be to open. You want the locks to operate without making the box difficult to spin fast enough.
Finally glue or screw the lid_base in place and test the final puzzle box.
I hope this give you as mush fun as I have had designing it.

This is my first functional design and print. It's not perfect but I'm pretty excited about it! The dock is made to work with this case http://www.spigen.com/iphone-6-case-neo-hybrid-4-7.html but I think a naked phone would still work fine. If not, the SKP is included to tweak as needed. I had hoped that the lightning end would tension fit into the hole but I was off by 1MM or so and ended up just hot gluing it in. Not as sexy, but it works great! If you do use the SKP, note that I had to use this model repair service https://modelrepair.azurewebsites.net/ to do some magic mumbo jumbo and get it to print. This is a replacement crank for these flashlights: http://www.harborfreight.com/pack-of-2-dynamo-led-flashlights-65207.html I bought these during the "Halloween Nor'easter" back in 2011. I broke the crank on one about 3 days into our power outage. At the time I fixed it with "plastic welding" (I stuck a large flathead screwdriver into a fireplace, then jammed it into the busted handle and melted it back together. Proper safety precautions were taken, don't try this at home.) but I have the tool to fix it properly now.

Print both parts. Disassemble the flashlight. Replace the crank. Reassemble the flashlight (I've included a picture of the gears and shafts in their correct places). Screw the knob to the crank (I used a #4 x1/2 wood screw). Crank it up!
Also needed a circuit breaker box to bolt to the side of my battery box.

This tile set has been superseded by the much improved OpenForge 2.0 Tudor set. That set is both more complete, and vastly better designed, please, check it out. OpenForge
=========
Tudor edge corridor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles.
These tiles are designed to line their wall up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbors. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    Changelog
    =========
    9/27/2014 - Found a new way to do wood that results in better/simpler models. Regenerated using that technique.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.

Printed in black. Dry brushed with dark brown and then used ever lighter shades in the dry brush. To lighten, used a light leather, not a white in order to get more yellow in the highlights.
The walls were painted in white, then mixed with the leather color, finally I stippled the walls with white again using a toothbrush.

This is jjshortcut's mini servo gripper (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2415) routerized and adapted for 6.7 mm plywood. I am using a 1.5 mm spiral cutter in 1 mm passes.
It appears to work great mechanically speaking (now need to make that servo shield....). Be sure to get metal gear mini servos instead of plastic geared ones, those are way too easy to destroy. Note: A further iteration of the design with improved gears can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5034

Cut and assemble. This one is quite straightforward, but be sure to leave a full plywood thickness space between the holder and the geared arms.
Screws are m3x30. Use superglue to block the nuts. In some future iteration, this design might benefit from real involuted gears. Have fun!

title: Nerf Star Lord Top Barrel Extension / Replacement

description.text: This top barrel is designed to replace the original orange barrel tip of a Nerf Star Lord Quad Blaster. These barrel tips render the gun incapable of firing Nerf darts, but also still allow the gun to open and close because I thought that was a really neat functionality of the base Nerf gun. You can use the same exact screws you removed from the original orange tips to affix these replacements. Some modifications to the base blaster are required to fit the top barrel into place. Specifically, you will have to trim some of the inside of the barrel cover (the part that moves) away. I did this with a Dremel, and would recommend you do the same - it makes it a lot easier. The barrel is designed with two 5mm holes to accommodate LEDs. How you go about doing that is up to you, but I've discovered the best effects (in my opinion) can be obtained by filling the barrels with clear resin to help diffuse the light fully down the barrel. You could also try lightly sanding some clear acrylic with a high-grit sandpaper and cutting it to shape to fit inside the barrel. I originally made these models to print on my Makergear M2, which prints at 100 micron (.1mm) resolution. They fit right onto the nerf guns straight off the print bed. Depending on your print setting, you may have to do a bit of sanding to get a proper fit.

comments.text: This looks like it was scaled in inches. When I converted the units to mm, it became much more reasonable.

author: FusedCreations

title: Nerf Star Lord Quad Blaster Bottom Barrel Replacement / Extension

description.text: This bottom barrel is designed to replace the original orange barrel tip of a Nerf Star Lord Quad Blaster. It prints in two pieces to save you the difficulty of dealing with trapped support structures; the cap covers the end of the underslung barrel section. These barrel tips render the gun incapable of firing Nerf darts, but also still allow the gun to open and close because I thought that was a really neat functionality of the base Nerf gun. You can use the same exact screws you removed from the original orange tips to affix these replacements. The barrel is designed with two 5mm holes to accommodate LEDs. How you go about doing that is up to you, but I've discovered the best effects (in my opinion) can be obtained by filling the barrels with clear resin to help diffuse the light fully down the barrel. You could also try lightly sanding some clear acrylic with a high-grit sandpaper and cutting it to shape to fit inside the barrel. I originally made these models to print on my Makergear M2, which prints at 100 micron (.1mm) resolution. They fit right onto the nerf guns straight off the print bed. Depending on your print settings, you you may have to do a bit of sanding to get a proper fit.

comments.text: Can you tell me what the scale should be for this?  When I add it to Makerbot it opens as a miniature scale 1.5mm tall.  If you could tell me the X, Y, or Z millimeter dimensions I would greatly appreciate it!  If you had it for the top barrel, that would be awesome too :)
comments.author: chadcham

comments.text: I believe it is the same for both.  They are measured in inches, rather than millimeters like your Makerbot is expecting.  That scale is 1:25.4, so you should scale it by 25.4 (2540%) if my math is correct.

title: Vaccuum Turbine Tool for CNC w/adjustable speed

description.text: This is a modification of RichMac's Turbine rotary Tool. I needed a tool for milling molds out of refractory sand, while also reducing dust and keeping Particulate out of the air. The Bearings and Shaft were sourced from Mcmaster-Carr and the chuck was sourced from amazon. Links contained below. A metal Lathe was used to drill a small hole in the end of the axle rod, and turn town the hex on the chuck into a smaller diameter shaft that was pressed into the axle. I'm sure a more clever solution exists, but I was in a bit of a rush. Balancing the large mass of the chuck with the axle is still a bit of a challenge and the tool only runs true at certain rpms. I Designed in a small  series of holes above the the turbine blades as a way to reduce vacuum pressure and thereby lower the rpms of the tool. While not refined to target a specific range of speeds, this does help to hone in on the ideal running speed at which the tool sounds best... more to come-

Source the following parts:
3 bearings (6mm ID, 13mm OD, 5mm WD)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#7804k113/=tyx2pu
1 rod (6mm)
http://www.mcmaster.com/#5544t252/=tyx2z6
1 chuck (1/4" keyless chuck conversion for power tools)
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007TCHKXW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
Print 2 of the Turbine Blade files, and one of everything else. Assemble per the rhino rhino/step file. I used a but of epoxy to attach the Chuck pin to the hole in the axle. The next variation will use an ER11 Shank and collet system.

comments.text: Looks nice, I had the same idea for my CNC but I have issues where my vacuum doesn't maintain a constant airflow and need an upgrade before I can feasibly use it. I'm looking forward to building one.

I was looking for an S Hook and was impressed with the original parameterised design.  Unfortunately, I needed an S Hook that had a greater distance between the two hook ends.  This design includes a length parameter which will automatically extend the S Hook if needed.

Using Open SCAD, change the required parameters to suit your needs and generate an STL file to print.  The instructions are consistent with the original S Hook. Just modify the new length parameter. I used a default length of 60mm for my garage hook. Setting the length to 0 will produce the same results as the original design. 
Using infill of around 12 % worked well for me when printing. Enjoy!

comments.text:
To speed up "compile and render", change the for loop in the module cutOpening.
The change will reduce the number of steps taken to make the opening on the hooks.
This is done by changing the step angle from -1 to -$fa/2.
$fa is the sytem variable that holds the fragment angle used for approximation of circles and cylinders.
Change
for(angle=[start:end]) {
to
for(angle=[start:-$fa/2:end]) {
comments.author: tweebs

comments.text: As long as angle is less than 180 degrees intersection of two cubes could speed things up even more (and achieve more accurate results). If it's over 180 the same intersection may be used in intersection instead of difference with the original cylinder. I did that locally along with putting cylinders at the end of the hook to make it smoother, now I need to find the file again and upload ;-)

remixed_from.title: Print Flat - Roll Into 3D, Heptagonal Column

title: FlatRoll with Adjustable Thickness, Pentagonal Column

description.text: Nophead commented on the original Heptagonal Column that Skeinforge would not print a zero thickness face... so I made this variant to show how easy it is to adjust the thickness of the bottom layer to exactly the value you want!

To adjust the thickness in Sketchup, select the push-pull command, use it on the bottom face, and (with snap/precision set to something compatible) adjust the thickness to exactly what you want.
You can also adjust the thickness of those triangles on the side with the same method.
Most CAD programs should support this method, altho the command might be named something like Extrude, perhaps.
The only piece of information you should need is the minimum thickness you can print. If someone can give that value for a Makerbot, I'm happy to make an STL file with the right thickness for someone to test print.

author: syvwlch

description.text:
I'm currently driving a new digital transmission electron microscope. The knobs which control the X and Y motion of the stage are so fluid and slick that they're hard to use, especially since I have to cover a large area (at least 1mm sq!) looking for virus particles.
Thus, this thing. It's sized to press-fit my stage control knobs, and has a fingertip indentation underneath (which becomes the top). Prints okay on a Makerbot in ABS even with the overhang. So now I can rest my fingertip on the indent of the knob and dial it to scan across large areas. Tested and it works.
Since it's unlikely that there are a lot of people out there needing a fix for the knobs on their H7600 TEM, and this is a stupid-easy CAD, I'm throwing this out into the 'verse as a concept: fix the knobs on the things you use every day.
Pic: note that the partial sphere used for the fingertip divot actually penetrates the bottom of the knob. Doesn't bother me, but you could make a smaller divot or make the knob thicker.
Resize to fit the top of the knob you need to improve. Print it out, stick it on. Drive.

author: FadiK

title: TOM template for acryl-plate with MORE LINES for laserengraver/-cutter

description.text:
This plate fits to on top of the standard TOM build plate if the acrylic that came with it is done.
In the illustrator you find thick lines for engraving and thin lines for marking and two lines for a big "+" to find the middle. holes for the screws are only hided and can be cut if wanted.
Like more to put the acrylic on top only with clips to fix or frame to hold.
Check the different layers in the *.ai for all the different options.
The original templates you can still find on thingiverse from makerbot. The bot here needed better adhesion for the first layer so came up with more lines for a rougher bed for better bonding. A good thing anyway: There exist actually single-piece bulldog-clips (fused multi parts) that make way less rattle-sound while the platform moves then the free-moving-multi-part bulldog-clips.

description.text: A simple adapter to use tools directly with a vacuum cleaner extension hose.

I'm surprised I didn't find anything like this already in the Thingiverse.  This is a simple adapter that lets you connect tools directly to a vacuum cleaner extension hose, letting you use the extension like a regular hose.
Because this thing is fairly tall and has a small bed contact area, I have provided an anchor pad to increase the bed surface area.  This reduces the possibility of the object coming loose while printing.  Just snip it out when finished.  It is easily commented out in the openscad file if you don't want that.  All of the major dimensions are parameterized to allow for easy tweaking.  Deafult height is 105 mm. but can be changed if desired.
Takes about 2 hours to print on my Printrbot+.

Background:
Modioworld, a robotic utopia were Modionics (robotic civilians) live peacefully and coexist with each other, is in constant danger from the evil that always lurks on the outskirts of this perfect society.
Thankfully, a group of ancient robotic guardians, called Gates, are always there to protect all that live in Modioworld.

author: roman_kzn

description.text:
Parts for my Hackaday Prize entry:
http://hackaday.io/project/2517-Entropy-Wheel-Heat-Recovery-Ventilator
These parts allow assembly without using expensive specialty glue and should save a lot of mess. They do take a VERY long time to print due to the amount of material used.
Pulley borrowed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:398999 .

These parts like to warp in ABS. They are meant to be printed with 100% infill for maximum strength as they will hold a 16" long x10" diametrer cylinder of coroplast sheets, about two full 4x8 ft x 4mm thick sheets. I took the suggestion of using ABS Glue - ABS + Acetone and painting over blue painters tape. That works great but Kapton is even better -- but it sticks too good and is harder to replace.
ABS glue is great for anti-warping but a nightmare to remove once done!
The honeycombs are used to accommodate the thickness of the sheet-holding clips to prevent air spillage between the hot and cold side of the thermal wheel. You will need to reference my Hackaday.io project to get the details on the Coroplast cutting. See my other Things for a Coroplast cutting tool. Another tool for cutting 16" cross-grain strips is in the works.
To make a full cylinder assembly, you need a Honeycomb Bearing Hub for the passive end and a Honeycomb Bearing Pulley Hub for the driven end. You need a total of 4x HE_Clip_Single_Rank_HC3 and 4x HC4 parts, 4x Honeycomb_HC3 and 4x Honeycomb HC4, and 4x Honeycomb_HC2 pieces. For the cutout Coroplast parts, two 4x8ft x 4mm Coroplast corrugated plastic from Home Depot (online). Note minimum order is 10 sheets @ $11 each.
Design of the heat exchanger is unfinished and untested, so I wouldn't rush out just yet...
The honeycomb functions may be useful for other things you might want to build. You just need to make the walls thick enough the slicer won't delete them.
Skate bearings press into the sockets on each end. A frame assembly to mate with the hub bearings is in the works.
Its an holder for the Blue tape...

Slightly thicker version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:439207 Case to keep contacts of a GoPro battery safe. Lip on the "tab" keeps the battery from falling out while in a bag / pocket. V1 has a 0.5mm lip
V2 has a 0.75mm lip 123D files added to make customization easier.
Designed with AutoDesk 123D Design and tested / printed with a Printrbot Simple 2014 (1401)

remixed_from.title: Virtual Reality Goggles for Android Smartphone

title: Sections Through Virtual Reality Goggles for Android Smartphone

description.text:
These files are posted to support the "Virtual Reality Goggles for Android Smartphone" by Croccy22;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:93460 Some people have found the fit to the face a bit small. I wanted a way to check this without printing the whole housing. I also wanted to check how well my phone would fit to the housing. So, I produced a couple of sections through the main housing (with OpenSCAD). The first is a 2mm thick section of the curve which fits to the head, the second is a 1mm thick section of the front face which fits to the phone. On my printer they take around 20 minutes each to print, rather than 5 hours for the whole housing.

No special instructions for printing.  
These are meant to print quickly, so you can decide if you want to print the whole housing or not.  
One the phone face section I've added spars to the gaps to make a one-piece model. These spars are slightly raised so they can be distinguished from the main section.

3 Assemble it

Es un diseño extremadamente sencillo para crear soportes para smartphones o tablets en corte láser y dm/mdf de 3mm. Designed by the students of architecture Juan Luís Solér & Iñigo Barahona Rodríguez and the workshop technician Juan Carlos Pérez Juidias in Seville`s Fablab.

Hi, here is my first self-made design.
It is made for my cheap 3$-Cree-Led-Flashlight.

You will be popular in your workplace with this one!  
This design contains 3 pieces which are snapped together to create a tray for carrying 4 or 5 cups from drink vending machines. Also provides a small recess for your change.  
Why not print it in white and write your orders directly on it?
EDIT (02/04/2016): One piece STL file added by request.

No special print instructions.  
The 3-piece design allows for printing on a small bed size.  
The design is 10mm thick to give good rigidity and stability to the simple dove-tail joints. The joints are deliberately tight but can be (firmly) pushed together without any need for fettling. Some glue could be added to the joint if desired.  
I'm sure there are better joint designs which could allow a thinner design (so quicker to print and using less material). Please feel free to Remix if you spot an improvement.

description.text:
This project involves the cutting of all components of the chair through a laser cutter from a plywood panel and then assembled according to traditional craft techniques.
Laser cutting becomes a necessary tool to create an object which blends into it craftsmanship knowlwdge, tradition and innovation, three elements that I believe are essential to the success of Italian design.
But there is a fourth element, the social function of the project: this is a product that will not be exported through slow and dusty trucks, planes or highly polluting, but through a simple e-mail.
Where there is a FabLab there is a potential place to produce this chair, green and cheap, because on the final price will insist only the cost of wood.

author: vangel

description.text:
This thing treats to suppress completely the undesired Z wobble effect in my BCN3D+. After try some setups without success, I decided to improve the Z axis with leadscrew M8x1,5 rods. The results are excellent!! never before I got the fine results achieved with this improvement.
enjoy & share your results !!! NOTICE: The optimal layer height for the Z-axis, changes with this new Leadscrew pitch (1.5). Check the optimal layer height in http://prusaprinters.org/calculator/#steppermotors in the "Optimal layer height" paragraph. You only need to enter the desired height and Leadscrew pitch and you will see the optimal layer value. i.e. for 0.2 the optimal layer is 0.195.

The parts affected are only the two Z motion parts where before were located the two M8 standard (with anti-backlash) nuts. Now I'm using an IGUS nut with the corresponding leadscrew rod. There are several international sites where to buy this parts but finally I decided to buy them in http://bcndynamics.com/ because is next to my home ;).
Firmware:

You have to update the steps done by the stepper motor in the Marlin firmware (define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {80.19,80.43,200.016/1.5,458.3} ) Note that I used the full equation (steps_per_mm = (motor_steps_per_rev driver_microstep) / thread_pitch)
Bill of materials:

• 2 x Ø8x1.5 Trapezoidal Leadscrew rod
  • 2 x Ø8x1.5 Trapezoidal Leadscrew nut
  • 2 x M3x12 DIN 912
  • 2 x M3 DIN 934

title: Mendel Max Pellow Block Y-carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Y-carriage to suit standard Mendel Max 1.5 using SCS8UU pellow blocks.
Set up for 100mm wide 8mm diameter rails.
Includes belt clamps for T2.5 6mm wide belt. Pellow blocks are manufactured bearing blocks and include integral LM8UU bearings.

Print it out.
Clean out the holes with 4mm drill for the pellow mounts and 3mm for the belt clamps. Cut a piece of 5mm thick aluminium (aluminum) sheet to 230mm square and mark out the carriage mount holes central and square to the edges. You could use a sheet of plywood as well but alloy looks nicer and will never warp. Drill the carriage mounting holes 4.5mm to clear the M4 machine screws and give some room for alignment.
You will also need a large central hole in the aluminium plate to let the wiring through, one large 50mm (2") hole will do. Bolt it to a 230mm square piece of 5mm thick aluminium with 8 of 50mm long M4 machine screws (the pellow blocks come tapped to M4).
Leave all 8 M4 screws loose and fit the carriage to the Y-axis rails.
Slowly tighten all 8 screws a little at a time whilst moving the carriage back an forth to allow it to self-align.
Finally tighten all M4 screws and it should move freely, ie with a light push.
